A wonderfully written and immensely enjoyable/hilarious play that lived up to all my expectations. Oscar Wilde is just one of those authors I can completely slip into at any time; he is the sole reason why I now love reading plays a lot more than I previously did. A Woman of No Importance is no exception.This play has a remarkably different moral compass than many of Oscarâ€™s other plays: whilst pretty much all the characters are ridiculous, there are some characters who are not quite as ridiculous as the others. Surprisingly, it is these characters who actually prevail at the end and that gives the play much more of a poignant note. This play is all about eradicating toxic relationships, making amendments for the past, learning that the past doesnâ€™t haunt you and follow you forever, and, above all, the fact that women and men should not be treated in any way differently! Neither is more superior than the other. (Unlike An Ideal Husband, which goes through phases of being very pro-male and then other phases of being very pro-female. That is, however, for comedy value, rather than being part of the genuine overall message.)A Woman of No Importance follows the young Gerald who has just been accepted as the secretary of the enormously popular ladiesâ€™ man Lord Illingworth. One of the few people who does NOT swoon before him is Mrs. Arbuthnot, Geraldâ€™s mother, who Lord I. describes as â€˜a woman of no importanceâ€™. As secrets are revealed, Gerald has to face a difficult moral quandary with regard to his family and his lover, Hester.  An extremely worthwhile play that I probably need to read again! Although Oscar Wildeâ€™s writing is quite easy to read, the plots themselves can actually be quite dense and full of extra themes, hence why reading it again is something I would definitely like to do to get even more out of it.

Dear Mr. Wilde, I beg your pardon sir. But... What the hell was this? You have recycled your characters from your other works, and you have copied almost exact dialogues. Example 1:The Picture of Dorian Gray (1890): "They say that when good Americans die they go to Paris," chuckled Sir Thomas, who had a large wardrobe of Humour's cast-off clothes. "Really! And where do bad Americans go to when they die?" inquired the duchess. "They go to America," murmured Lord Henry.A Woman of No Importance (1893): MRS ALLONBY. They say, Lady Hunstanton, that when good Americans die they go to Paris. LADY HUNSTANTON. Indeed? And when bad Americans die, where do they go to? LORD ILLINGWORTH. Oh, they go to America.Example 2:The Picture of Dorian Gray (1890): "Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both are disappointed."A Woman of No Importance (1893): LORD ILLINGWORTH. Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.Are you serious? So sleazy and lazy of you. And this is only 2 examples. The whole play is full of this, I could go on forever. Also the play is the same social commentary that we have all heard from you before. You are not a one trick pony, are you?I have not read all of your works but I have read a fair amount, heck I even have read Dorian Gray eight times. Did you really think that I would not notice? I am disappointed to be frank, but on the bright side, I still enjoyed the play and found the last scene and ending to be powerful. Anyway, next time I am in Paris, I am gonna come to see you in the XXe arrondissement and we are gonna have a chat about this. Cordialement, M.

Not for me to critique the classics, so I won't try.The edition in which this play appeared also included 4 other works by Mr. Wilde, including Lady Windermere's Fan, which I read before I read A Woman of No Importance and The Importance of Being Earnest, which I will read before I return this volume to the library.These plays are a fascinating (satirical and humorous) glimpse of society at the turn of the century, when the titled lords and ladies of England were scrambling to maintain their "natural dominance" over the middle and lower classes. I learned that the middle class was the most disturbing, as they had the temerity to work and earn money on their own as opposed to inheriting it. Then there are those pesky wealthy merchant Americans who were marrying their most eligible men and introducing all sorts of uncomfortable notions like equality for all. See, for instance, the conversation between Lady Caroline and her American visitor, Hestor Worsley:LC -- "In my young days, Miss Worsley, one never met anyone in society who worked for their living. It was not considered the thing."HW -- "In America those are the people we admire the most."LC -- "I have no doubt of it."The long-standing inequality of social consequences when an unmarried woman bears a child is really the focus of this particular play. Interesting to see that this issue was being addressed publicly (not without shock and horror on the part of some, no doubt) in 1893 and yet some of the same beliefs still resonate today.

"A Woman of No Importance effectively argues against all sexual laws and restrictions, showing them to be both ineffectual against the power of passion and impulse, and a potent weapon in the hands of those who choose to exploit them. Mrs. Arbuthnot struggles with an absolute morality that denies all her true instincts as a woman, finding in the melodramatic role of injured innocent both a relief from her own guilt and a means of retaining possession of her son.... Wildeâ€™s sympathies do not obviously lie with either sex. The subtle and intricate pattern of power he reveals simply reflects the hypocrisy and manipulation that result from the imposition of any law upon human behavior.... The true centre of A Woman of No Importance is this interaction between human nature and the laws which seek to confine it."(Eltis, Sos. Revising Wilde : Society and Subversion in the Works of Oscar Wilde. Oxford : Clarendon P, 1996)This review makes me think about The Portrait of Dorian Gray and the ways Dorian's behaviour can't be fixed by society's rules, even the ones made by Victorian society - such as how to be well-behaved in the aristocratic society. Having recently read American Psycho, another example of someone who should present good behaviours because of his social position in society, you start to wonder about the effectiveness of rules in society and the truth behind human nature. Is human truly that bad and can rules truly fix them, or is it the rules that push humans to break them and therefore develop bad behaviours? ~in my philosophy era

4.5 stars''A man who can dominate a London dinner-table can dominate the world.''There's nothing more entertaining than Oscar Wilde's take on members of the English upper society engaging in idle conversation and gossip. I'd happily read a full-length novel about these characters being frivolous and very, very quotable. I have never really harboured acting aspirations, but it's a testament to Wilde's talent that reading his work often makes me wonder what'd be like to put on a production, deliver witty one-liners, and simply relish the effortless flow of dialogue that makes every Oscar Wilde play a work of beauty and genius. The world has always laughed at its own tragedies, that being the only way in which it has been able to bear them.Oscar Wilde uses the plot of A Woman of No Importance to comment on many things including class divide and the upper society's hypocritical attitudes towards gender expectations and dynamics.

I am stunned.... I don't usually write goodreads reviews but 'A Woman of No Importance' really touched me so I feel like I must write something. The play started off as hilarious, (I couldn't prevent myself from laughing out loud) but it took a really serious turn towards the middle/end. The social commentary, as is usually the case with Oscar Wilde, was brilliant and the ending was extremely powerful. Here is one quote that I felt was particularly stirring:"I will not. You talk of atonement for a wrong done. What atonement can be made to me? There is no atonement possible. I am disgraced; he is not. That is all. It is the usual history of a man and a woman as it usually happens, as it always happens. And the ending is the ordinary ending. The woman suffers. The man goes free."I apologise for the crappy review but wow, what a way to end the year.

This play may not be as dramatic and engaging as others of Wilde's, but ooh that final line! Again Wilde tackles the subject of gender equality, this time through the conceit of a reunited pair of former lovers and an unbeknownst son. It's actually rather ridiculous that Victorian society treated jilted women in such a way, but interesting that Wilde gave his character a believable success story and an ultimate revenge on the man who mistreated her! I wonder if after the story ends the ne'er do well man actually disappears as he's been made to do, but even more importantly if the woman and her son (and presumably daughter-in-law) will go to America and live far away from the trite scandals of England. This being the second play I've read of Wilde's which emphasizes the benefits of American society over English, I am starting to detect a theme and Wilde has revealed his obvious disdain for England. Interesting for a man so wrapped up in its society...

LADY STUTFIELD. Ah! The world was made for men and not for women. MRS. ALLONBY. Oh, don't say that, Lady Stutfield. We have a much better time than they have. There are far more things forbidden to us than are forbidden to them.In this drawing-room comedy, Wilde sharply criticizes the British societyâ€™s different moral standards for women and men. Women are harshly punished, while men walk away. He also admires the Americanâ€™s â€œPuritanâ€ values, egalitarianism and straight talk, which are embodied in the young American girl, Hester Worsley. All of which is wrapped in Wildeâ€™s usual free-wheeling wit. Like other of his works, this one is full of sharp quotes.

a popular man, an important part in the london society, Mr. Illingworth hires a secretary Gerald Arbuthnot. amidst many interesting conversations of the side characters about society, women, youth, marriage, some details of the past of this man are unravelled upon us. with the very quotable dialogues we later discover what he did and how it effects Mr. Arbuthnot in the present day. the writing was admirable as it always is with Wilde and i especially loved how strong the characters were. and the feminist aspects of this play! it had a very important woman character who i was afraid would disappoint me at the end but she didn't. the ending totally satisfied me and i loved it so much.

I really enjoyed this play! I'm taking an Oscar Wilde class this semester, and we're entering the play unit, and I think this was a good way to introduce his longford work. Personally, I think it's a crime that Wilde only wrote one novel. I think his characterization is so strong within his plays, which is amazing considering we lack a lot of the inner characterization and description that a novel can afford. This take on the idea of the single Victorian mother is well done, with the play ending without her having to marry Lord Illingworth to atone for her sins. 10/10 This play had feminism.Honestly, I overall really enjoyed it. The only reason I gave it 4 stars was because I found the first act to be pretty slow and unnecessary for the actual plot of the play.

This was fuckin' brilliant. I'm still high on how satisfying the ending was. Lady Arbuthnot slapping Lord Illingworth across his stupid smug face (I actually cackled when she did that) and then heading off to get her happy ending (or at least have hope for one) was great. As soon as this dude verbatim said one of Lord Henry Wotton's lines, I knew he was gonna be an asshole and was I fuckin' proven right.The last line of the play was just *muah* and the whole play was just UUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUU-Anyway.Good night.

Me at Oscar Wilde's plays: ''And you get five stars! And you get five stars! And YOU get five stars!''Wow wow wow.This is utterly brilliant. Wilde's wit and humour is at its best and - as always - the play is very quotable. A Woman of No Importance  might be Wilde's most feminist work. Its message and last line are amazing. I cannot stress enough how much I love this play.So... in case this has not clear before: I recommend this play to everyone!

3.5play for class. oscar wilde is so fucking witty; his writing is so singular and charming that i just fall in love with him every time. this is my first play of his, and itâ€™s melodramatic as hell but satirical in its melodrama, and i thoroughly enjoyed my time with it â€” found myself smiling most of the way through. it has real punch too; it very clearly emphasizes and supports the role of single women in the late 19th century. it is pointed and articulated tactfully, and has a sprinkle of that dorian gray pizzazz that iâ€™ve realized iâ€™ve missed so much.

A charming delight that touches on serious issues. It's almost as if Wilde were writing a rather pointed response to Scandinavian serious drama of Ibsen and Strindberg. Those two authors make of infidelity and illegitimacy an agonized drama, whereas Wilde dances on these subjects as though he were laughing explicitly at the overwrought hand-wringing and agonizing of those dramatists.

I really enjoyed this. It would make an excellent book club read; there would be a lot to discuss on a moral level. I would love to see this performed, too. Itâ€™s one of those tricky works where you donâ€™t quite know whose side to be on because the main characters, even when they seem quite awful, have a human face. I will definitely be re-reading this in the future.

MRS. ALLONBY. The Ideal Husband? There couldn't be such a thing. The institution is wrong. LADY STUTFIELD. The Ideal Man, then, in his relations to US. LADY CAROLINE. He would probably be extremely realistic. MRS. CAROLINE. The Ideal Man! Oh, the Ideal Man should talk to us as if we were goddesses, and treat us as if we were children. He should refuse all our serious requests, and gratify every one of our whims. He should encourage us to have caprices, and forbid us to have missions. He should always say much more than he means, and always mean much more than he says.LADY HUNSTANTON. But how could he do both, dear? MRS. ALLONBY. He should never run down other pretty women. That would show he had no taste, or make one suspect that he had too much. No; he should be nice about them all, but say that somehow they don't attract him. LADY STUTFIELD. Yes, that is always very, very pleasant to hear about other women. MRS. ALLONBY. If we ask him a question about anything, he should give us an answer all about ourselves. He should invariably praise us for whatever qualities he knows we haven't got. But he should be pitiless, quite pitiless, in reproaching us for the virtues that we have never dreamed of possessing. He should never believe that we know the use of useful things. That would be unforgiveable. But he should shower on us everything we don't want. LADY CAROLINE. As far as I can see, he is to do nothing but pay bills and compliments. MRS. ALLONBY. He should persistently compromise us in public, and treat us with absolute respect when we are alone. And yet he should be always ready to have a perfectly terrible scene, whenever we want one, and to become miserable, absolutely miserable, at a moment's notice, and to overwhelm us with just reproaches in less than twenty minutes, and to be positively violent at the end of half an hour, and to leave us for ever at a quarter to eight, when we have to go and dress for dinner. And when, after that, one has seen him for really the last time, and he has refused to take back the little things he has given one, and promised never to communicate with one again, or to write one any foolish letters, he should be perfectly broken-hearted, and telegraph to one all day long, and send one little notes every half-hour by a private hansom, and dine quite alone at the club, so that every one should know how unhappy he was. And after a whole dreadful week, during which one has gone about everywhere with one's husband, just to show how absolutely lonely one was, he may be given a third last parting, in the evening, and then, if his conduct has been quite irreproachable, and one has behaved really badly to him, he should be allowed to admit that he has been entirely in the wrong, and when he has admitted that, it becomes a woman's duty to forgive, and one can do it all over again from the beginning, with variations. LADY HUNSTANTON. How clever you are, my dear! You never mean a single word you say. LADY STUTFIELD. Thank you, thank you. It has been quite, quite entrancing. I must try and remember it all. There are such a number of details that are so very, very important. LADY CAROLINE. But you have not told us yet what the reward of the Ideal Man is to be. MRS. ALLONBY. His reward? Oh, infinite expectation. That is quite enough for him.********************************************************************************************GERALD. It is very difficult to understand women, is it not? LORD ILLINGWORTH. You should never try to understand them. Women are pictures. Men are problems. If you want to know what a woman really means - which, by the way, is always a dangerous thing to do - look at her, don't listen to her. GERALD. But women are awfully clever, aren't they? LORD ILLINGWORTH. One should always tell them so. But, to the philosopher, my dear Gerald, women represent the triumph of matter over mind - just as men represent the triumph of mind over morals. GERALD. How then can women have so much power as you say they have? LORD ILLINGWORTH. The history of women is the history of the worst form of tyranny the world has ever known. The tyranny of the weak over the strong. It is the only tyranny that lasts. GERALD. But haven't women got a refining influence? LORD ILLINGWORTH. Nothing refines but the intellect. GERALD. Still, there are many different kinds of women, aren't there? LORD ILLINGWORTH. Only two kinds in society: the plain and the coloured.GERALD. But there are good women in society, aren't there? LORD ILLINGWORTH. Far too many. GERALD. But do you think women shouldn't be good? LORD ILLINGWORTH. One should never tell them so, they'd all become good at once. Women are a fascinatingly wilful sex. Every woman is a rebel, and usually in wild revolt against herself. GERALD. You have never been married, Lord Illingworth, have you? LORD ILLINGWORTH. Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.

The Woman of No Importance is in fact "important" because it addresses an issue as old as mankind... When we don't understand, we fear, when we fear, we create all these hierarchies and social barriers and engage ourselves in class wars, social wars, nation wars, wit wars, you name it. This short play lays out so much that is wrong in sticking to your guns.

I found this one a little tedious. It was neither as witty as The Importance of being Earnest nor as moving as Lady Windermere's fan. Like the latter, it touched upon women's unfortunate and precarious place in Society, and on the pain of motherhood. Yet as opposed to Mrs Erlynne, Mrs Arbuthnot was more verbose than demonstrative. That is not to say that I did not sympathize with her plight. Rachel Arbuthnot, who had her son Gerald out of wedlock, discovers suddenly that the man who got her pregnant then refused to marry her, George Harford, now Lord Illingworth, wants to hire Gerald as his private secretary. She is of course devastated to have this man back in her life, and trying to take her son away from her no less. For his part, Illingworth, an immoral and wildly sexist misanthrope, takes the news entirely in stride, and is very pleased to discover Gerald is his son. He almost succeeds in removing him from Rachel, when due to an ill-advised bet with the other completely immoral character of the play, Mrs Allonby, he makes unwanted advances on the girl Gerald is in love with, American heiress Hester Worsley. Gerald is driven to incredible anger and threatens to kill him, before his mother intervenes to stop him, as he cannot possibly kill his own father.Gerald then tries to insist that Mrs Arbuthnot must marry the man who ruined her life, "for her own sake". Her impassioned speech in response to this is worth recording: Mrs. Arbuthnot: I do not know it. I do not feel it, nor will I ever stand before Godâ€™s altar and ask Godâ€™s blessing on so hideous a mockery as a marriage between me and George Harford. I will not say the words the Church bids us to say. I will not say them. I dare not. How could I swear to love the man I loathe, to honour him who wrought you dishonour, to obey him who, in his mastery, made me to sin? No: marriage is a sacrament for those who love each other. It is not for such as him, or such as me. Gerald, to save you from the worldâ€™s sneers and taunts I have lied to the world. For twenty years I have lied to the world. I could not tell the world the truth. Who can, ever? But not for my own sake will I lie to God, and in Godâ€™s presence. No, Gerald, no ceremony, Church-hallowed or State-made, shall ever bind me to George Harford. It may be that I am too bound to him already, who, robbing me, yet left me richer, so that in the mire of my life I found the pearl of price, or what I thought would be so.Gerald: I donâ€™t understand you now.Mrs. Arbuthnot: Men donâ€™t understand what mothers are. I am no different from other women except in the wrong done me and the wrong I did, and my very heavy punishments and great disgrace. And yet, to bear you I had to look on death. To nurture you I had to wrestle with it. Death fought with me for you. All women have to fight with death to keep their children. Death, being childless, wants our children from us. Gerald, when you were naked I clothed you, when you were hungry I gave you food. Night and day all that long winter I tended you. No office is too mean, no care too lowly for the thing we women loveâ€”and oh! how I loved you. Not Hannah, Samuel more. And you needed love, for you were weakly, and only love could have kept you alive. Only love can keep any one alive. And boys are careless often and without thinking give pain, and we always fancy that when they come to manâ€™s estate and know us better they will repay us. But it is not so. The world draws them from our side, and they make friends with whom they are happier than they are with us, and have amusements from which we are barred, and interests that are not ours: and they are unjust to us often, for when they find life bitter they blame us for it, and when they find it sweet we do not taste its sweetness with them . . . You made many friends and went into their houses and were glad with them, and I, knowing my secret, did not dare to follow, but stayed at home and closed the door, shut out the sun and sat in darkness. What should I have done in honest households? My past was ever with me. . . . And you thought I didnâ€™t care for the pleasant things of life. I tell you I longed for them, but did not dare to touch them, feeling I had no right. You thought I was happier working amongst the poor. That was my mission, you imagined. It was not, but where else was I to go? The sick do not ask if the hand that smooths their pillow is pure, nor the dying care if the lips that touch their brow have known the kiss of sin. It was you I thought of all the time; I gave to them the love you did not need: lavished on them a love that was not theirs . . . And you thought I spent too much of my time in going to Church, and in Church duties. But where else could I turn? Godâ€™s house is the only house where sinners are made welcome, and you were always in my heart, Gerald, too much in my heart. For, though day after day, at morn or evensong, I have knelt in Godâ€™s house, I have never repented of my sin. How could I repent of my sin when you, my love, were its fruit! Even now that you are bitter to me I cannot repent. I do not. You are more to me than innocence. I would rather be your motherâ€”oh! much rather!â€”than have been always pure . . . Oh, donâ€™t you see? donâ€™t you understand? It is my dishonour that has made you so dear to me. It is my disgrace that has bound you so closely to me. It is the price I paid for youâ€”the price of soul and bodyâ€”that makes me love you as I do. Oh, donâ€™t ask me to do this horrible thing. Child of my shame, be still the child of my shame!Overall however this felt a little bit like the plot of one of those silly Christmas movies, with the poor hardworking mother, the immoral estranged father, the honest son who is ignorant of his family history, and the beautiful, rich, and good woman who loves him and ends up saving everyone. And it was really tedious, so much so that it did not feel like Wilde's writing in places.Some lines were however very good, either incredibly hilarious or scathing social commentary that remains valuable. Particularly Illingworth's comment that the problem of poverty is actually an issue of slavery, and that the very rich understand charity as a means of distracting the poor from the reality of their situation, stands even today, as poverty remains a widespread and pressing problem in the UK. Mrs. Allonby: But somehow, I feel sure that if I lived in the country for six months, I should become so unsophisticated that no one would take the slightest notice of me.Lady Hunstanton: I assure you, dear, that the country has not that effect at all. Why, it was from Melthorpe, which is only two miles from here, that Lady Belton eloped with Lord Fethersdale. I remember the occurrence perfectly. Poor Lord Belton died three days afterwards of joy, or gout. I forget which. We had a large party staying here at the time, so we were all very much interested in the whole affair.Mrs. Allonby: I think to elope is cowardly. Itâ€™s running away from danger. And danger has become so rare in modern life.*Lady Stutfield: The world says that Lord Illingworth is very, very wicked.Lord Illingworth: But what world says that, Lady Stutfield? It must be the next world. This world and I are on excellent terms. Lady Stutfield: Every one I know says you are very, very wicked.Lord Illingworth: It is perfectly monstrous the way people go about, nowadays, saying things against one behind oneâ€™s back that are absolutely and entirely true.*Lady Caroline: These American girls carry off all the good matches. Why canâ€™t they stay in their own country? They are always telling us it is the Paradise of women.Lord Illingworth: It is, Lady Caroline. That is why, like Eve, they are so extremely anxious to get out of it.*Lady Hunstanton: Politics are in a sad way everywhere, I am told. They certainly are in England. Dear Mr. Cardew is ruining the country. I wonder Mrs. Cardew allows him. I am sure, Lord Illingworth, you donâ€™t think that uneducated people should be allowed to have votes?Lord Illingworth: I think they are the only people who should.Kelvil: Do you take no side then in modern politics, Lord Illingworth?Lord Illingworth: One should never take sides in anything, Mr. Kelvil. Taking sides is the beginning of sincerity, and earnestness follows shortly afterwards, and the human being becomes a bore. However, the House of Commons really does very little harm. You canâ€™t make people good by Act of Parliament,â€”that is something.Kelvil: You cannot deny that the House of Commons has always shown great sympathy with the sufferings of the poor.Lord Illingworth: That is its special vice. That is the special vice of the age. One should sympathise with the joy, the beauty, the colour of life. The less said about lifeâ€™s sores the better, Mr. Kelvil.Kelvil: Still our East End is a very important problem.Lord Illingworth: Quite so. It is the problem of slavery. And we are trying to solve it by amusing the slaves.Lady Hunstanton: Certainly, a great deal may be done by means of cheap entertainments, as you say, Lord Illingworth. Dear Dr. Daubeny, our rector here, provides, with the assistance of his curates, really admirable recreations for the poor during the winter. And much good may be done by means of a magic lantern, or a missionary, or some popular amusement of that kind.(...)Kelvil: May I ask, Lord Illingworth, if you regard the House of Lords as a better institution than the House of Commons?Lord Illingworth: A much better institution, of course. We in the House of Lords are never in touch with public opinion. That makes us a civilised body.*Lady Hunstanton: Are you going, Mrs. Allonby?Mrs. Allonby: Just as far as the conservatory. Lord Illingworth told me this morning that there was an orchid there as beautiful as the seven deadly sins.Lady Hunstanton: My dear, I hope there is nothing of the kind. I will certainly speak to the gardener.

I did not think much of this at first, I must admit. Wilde reused many lines/quotes from his other works, as is evident here. However, I am glad to admit that further reading proved me wrong, and this play is a tremendous improvement over 'Lady Windermere's Fan' in terms of subject matter and themes.Lord Illingworth is so much similar to Lord Henry in 'The Picture of Dorian Gray'. He is regarded as wicked, and indeed a bad influence. His philosophies of life are selfish, intrinsically hedonistic and 'dangerous'. Others succumb to his wit and charm though, he is considered to be the 'life' in many parties. Nobody objected when Lord Illingworth assigned a certain youth, Gerald Arbuthnot, to be his secretary abroad. Many were happy for the young man, as Gerald had no family titles or fortune. The surprise twist is in the character of Mrs Arbuthnot, Gerald's mother. For some reason she objected heavily against her son dealing with such a man, even if Lord Illingworth proposed a bright future for her son. Being unmarried, however, Mrs Arbuthnot is regarded as a woman of no importance, and her only son (initially) paid no heed to her advice. Gerald thinks that his post as secretary to Lord Illingworth will ascertain his marriage to Miss Hester Worsley, the 'Puritan' American. I will not reveal the surprise twist at the end of the play, but this much I can say; This play emphasizes the discriminating English Society of the late 19th Century. It was alright for an unmarried man to elope with any one he wished, and still be regarded as the most interesting person in a party. However, the woman the man elopes with is ruined forever, psychologically and socially. She is then considered in society as a woman of no importance, of no consequence. This play reveals how unjust society was at that time against women. One feels considerable pity for Mrs Arbuthnot, but Wilde makes her as a 'hero' character in this play. Despite the callousness of such a society, Mrs Arbuthnot emerges triumphant both as a mother and a woman. She resists the taunts of Lord Illingworth's claim on not just her son, but on her as well. With all his money and property,Lord Illingworth is revealed in the end as a hollow and manipulative character, indeed, a man of no importance... Without revealing the surprise twist, I attempted to at least try to explain the play's underlying theme. Wilde writes in such an elegant manner, that it is hard not to enjoy any of his plays.

Well of course, Oscar Wilde doesn't need a stamp of approval. But I feel compelled to talk about his work because I don't want anyone to miss the pleasure of reading him. And the best thing is that most of his work is available on project Gutenberg.The first book by him that I read, was The Picture of Dorian Gray. The book shook me so much that I couldn't complete it. It was real and it changed my perspective on life. I'm planning to complete it this year.Now, on to 'A woman of no importance'. I know that technically, it's not a book. And I tried to get an audio book of people voice-acting it. But, I didn't like it that much, so I decided to read it. This was the first time I have ever read a play by Oscar Wilde and it was the most amazing experience ever! Every dialogue was superb. So much thought has been put into this short and simple script that you can read it time and again and be amazed by the depth of writing. Wilde's self-contradictory style of philosophizing is a delight to read.I don't think there's anyone who has a better grasp on the complicated nature of human relationships than Oscar Wilde. He uses that to make this play about the relationships so much more profound!I'll just stop at that because I'm not qualified to say more about the play than that it is a beautifully written story, replete with brilliant aphorisms. See for yourself.Since it's such a short play, you can even read it online. The University of Adelaide has a beautiful online version that I recommend.Twenty-sixth book reviewed as part of the 130 Challenge | Read on my blog

"A Woman of No Importance" stands as an everlasting monument, bearing testament to Wilde's unassailable genius in blending scintillating wit, caustic satire, and societal introspection. It is an iridescent tapestry, meticulously woven with indelible characters and intellectually invigorating discourse. Whether one is an ardent devotee of Wilde's prodigious talents or merely seeks the thrill of a masterfully crafted play, "A Woman of No Importance" stands resolute as an imperative literary sojourn, leaving an indelible imprint upon the grand tapestry of human nature and the relentless judgment of society.

From my review of The Importance of Being Earnest and Other Plays: "A Woman of No Importance" returns us to Wilde's present day, and it's quite amusing as well. "Oscar Wilde's audacious drama of social scandal centres around the revelation of Mrs Arbuthnot's long-concealed secret. A house party is in full swing at Lady Hunstanton's country home, when it is announced that Gerald Arbuthnot has been appointed secretary to the sophisticated, witty Lord Illingworth. Gerald's mother stands in the way of his appointment, but fears to tell him why, for who will believe Lord Illingworth to be a man of no importance?" I really loved the banter between Lord Illingsworth and Mrs. Allonby; they're both rather nasty people, but they certainly get along pretty well, and have interesting conversations. In the notes, it's pointed out that Wilde originally had many of the quips written just for Lord Illingsworth, but dividing them up cemented the rapport between the two characters. It was certainly effective, and I enjoyed reading their exchanges. "A Woman Of No Importance" had a great plot, and it was also quite moving and skillfully, subtly written. There were several amusing quips, most of them said by Lord Illingsworth. For example, he says, "one should never take sides in anything...taking sides is the beginning of sincerity, and earnestness follows shortly afterwards, and the human being becomes a bore." I found that quite interesting and funny; it's also sort of true. I was fascinated by the character of Lord Illingsworth; he rather cruelly manipulates Mrs. Arbuthnot, verbally and pyschologically, yet he has a charm about him. He's more than just the stereotypically cruel and wanton villain. Wilde portrays all the characters and their relationships so, so well, in this play and all of the others. www.novareviews.blogspot.com

a woman of no importance is a play that's full of humor, wit, and scandal. it's like a victorian-era gossip girl, but with less technology and more tea. honestly, the characters and their conversations are a blast to read. you'll find yourself rooting for some and laughing at others, all while feeling like you're getting an inside look into the world of high society. so if you're looking for a fun and entertaining read that's not too heavy, this is the perfect pick!

'A Woman of No Importance' is perhaps one of the most significant contributions of Wilde to English Literature. A crisp slap on the face of a hypocritical society like that of the late 19th century England, this play is entertaining, interesting and deeply moving. A craft of Wilde's immeasurable wit, 'A Woman of No Importance' has some absolutely ridiculous characters like Mrs. Allonby, a hopeless coquette, Lady Caroline Pontefract, an annoyingly bossy woman (who could be Hermione Granger's great grand-aunt) and Lady Stutfield, a naÃ¯ve and rather foolish woman who shows her deficiency in vocabulary by repetition of phrases like 'Very, very' and her idiocy by dumbly agreeing to everybody's opinion and following none. There is the Archdeacon Daubeny, whose wife was so talented once in every field known and is so ill now that it's a medical miracle she's still alive!And then there's Lord Illingworth a character so hideous and adorable at he same time, you know not what to feel about him! He's full of wise sayings, some of which arouse deep sympathy for him, some which totally repulse the reader. He is a sinner, a victim, an honourable man and a wretch all at the same time. But the strongest character in the play is Mrs. Arbuthnot, who, though called 'A Woman of No Importance' is Wilde's spokeswoman and the most important character in the entire play, who gives it a new turn and through the means of her emotional strength, gives it a new ending!

"A Woman of No Importance" is another of Oscar Wilde's "Society Plays," and it certainly carries on his portrayal of English capital-s "Society" as being vapid, shallow, and cruel. In this case, the title is ironic, since Mrs. Arbuthnot is one of the only decent characters in the play.The play starts at a country estate, where Sir John Pontefract and his wife are entertaining guests. Among them is Hester Worsley, a young woman visiting from America. She and Gerald Arbuthnot--son of Mrs Arbuthnot--have been dating. Gerald has just accepted a job as Secretary to Lord Illingworth, an oily and venomously charming bachelor. Gerald is excited by the new position, as it will provide him the means with which to marry Hester. Also, Lord Illingworth serves as a type of ideal for Gerald, who grew up fatherless. The clashes between Lord Illingworth, Hester, Gerald, and his mother shine against the dull emptiness of the various Lords and Ladies also in attendance. I grew weary of this play by halfway through the second act. Wilde writes splendid epigrams, but sometimes all the other characters exist to feed Lord Illingworth set-up lines. It's like comedy skeet.In the third and fourth acts, though, Wilde really develops his story. The play reveals a secret or two, and it works toward a surprisingly satisfying conclusion. If you get bogged down early on, as I did, stick it out. Oscar knew what he was doing after all.

"Hearts live by being wounded. Pleasure may turn a heart to stone, riches may make it callous, but sorrow - oh, sorrow cannot break it." Wilde's A Woman of No Importance is expectedly a witty drawing room play regarding societal and gender norms, targeting specifically "disgraced" women. The First Act sets up the dialogue between upperclass women and their discussions on how they view other women and men alike, showcasing the unreasonable standards and vastly different views on women. It highlights the stark views Lord Illingworth has on women, especially, and as the Acts continue, it only progressively shows how unfair "fallen" women are treated, and how easily women are written off as women of no importance. The ending is satisfying and immensely touching, through a discussion between a mother and son, and a woman who finally takes Arbuthnot's side despite how hard Arbuthnot is on herself for her past mistakes. Despite the entertaining dialogue and exciting unfolding of events in the later acts, I found that there was a bit disconnect between the characters and overall, at many points, was bored.Regardless, Wilde created a very interesting drawing room play focused on exhausting double standards in the Victorian Era.

Another play dealing with lies and secrets that ultimately make for a very interesting read. I've just begun to place certain quotes in these reviews. These lines I underlined while reading and this will make it easier for me to look back on. It also serves as a way for those interested in reading the story to get a feel of what the writing is like. As you can see Mr. Wilde is a very quotable man. "Sentiment is all very well for the buttonhole.""Talk to every woman as if you loved her, and to every man as if he bored you.""Woman are pictures. Men are problems." "Men marry because they are tired; woman because they are curious. Both are disappointed.""For the world has been made by fools that wise men should live in it.""My wrongs are my own, and I will bear them alone."

At first this play is of a humorous quality only the finest wit can produce. But then it changes. I understand why critics would call it sentimental and moralistic. I just don't care.If you're a woman you might sympathise throughly with Mrs. Arbuthnot. I did at least, so much that by act iv nothing mattered to me but her long deserved happiness, peace of mind, forgiveness, whatever you'd call it. All wit being thrown around was vanity and I couldn't stand by it anymore. I also could not begin to imagine what was it that could ever make up for this woman's ordeal. But that's ok, because Wilde got it. He always gets it in the end.

In the light of Oscar Wilde and his precious aesthetes movement, I understand the irony of the following statement, but I must express it: this was literally nothing. The aesthetes weren't existentialists, so why is the muck which fits into the genre such futile garbage?I was pretty disappointed in my boy Oscar. This was chatter for the sake of chatter. Maybe he'd lost a bet. I gave it a star because of its slight shadowings of female equality and for the following quote: Lord Illingworth: Women have become too brilliant. Nothing spoils a romance so much as a sense of humour in the woman.Mrs. Allonby: Or the want of it in the man.

2.5 stars If you asked me a week ago about Oscar Wilde i would of said â€œHe's the manâ€ now i'd say he's still the man but this isn't his best work, the characters here felt "borrowed" from his previous works, like Mrs Arbuthnot is identical to Mrs Erlynne from 'Lady Windermere's Fan' and Lord Illingworth was Lord Henry from 'The Picture of Dorian Gray' in disguise. There's nothing like a Oscar Wilde play to slate the late 19th Century English Aristocracy. Apparently, this play is not considered one of his best, however, I enjoyed it just as much as the other works of Wilde that I've read (Lady Windermere's Fan and Salome). Lady Caroline and Lady Hunstanton are insufferable, Lord Illingworth and Mrs Allonby, the cynics. Packed with clever and quotable lines. Amusing. Much sympathy for Mrs Arbuthnot - her speech about motherhood in Act 4 is excellent. Plenty of gender politics highlighting the injustices of a male-dominated society.

This play is not the typical Oscar Wilde comedy, but rather a drama that has some amusing lines. It's fairly melodramatic at times and a bit preachy. The most interesting aspect of the plot is what seems to be his use of Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter, as if he sought to explore how the situation of Hester Prynne and Arthur Dimmesdale would play out in non-Puritan, late Victorian English society. Wilde's resolution, much like Hawthorne's would probably still have given Mrs. Hawthorne a headache, but that's not a bad thing.

Oscar Wilde is always a good read if one is in the mood for something quotable that can be read in a single sitting. This play has the added element of the strange/amusing sort of misogyny one only gets from a gay man writing a work with a (superficially, anyway) feminist message. Wilde does a deliberately excellent job of making the "moral" of the story seem rather silly.That acknowledged and set aside, I enjoyed the play.

I think this is the best of Wilde's plays. It has some of his typical witty lines with jibes at "polite society" and its expectations of people but he goes beyond that as well. In some of Wilde's plays I feel his characters are more cardboard cutouts than round, feeling people. This play is an exception, however. He addresses real social issues and gender roles in dialogue filled with passion and real emotion.

A woman of no importance introduces us to Mrs Arbuthnot, a woman with a past. In this instance, however the lady wishes neither to forgive nor to forget. As a matter of fact, she relishes her self imposed martyrdom since it enables her to possess her son (Gerald) with a clear and righteous conscience. Gerald, an ambitious young man,meets Lord Illingworth a man who guarantees him a golden future under his sponsorship. Unfortunately the titles gentleman is the man who abandoned Mrs Arbuthnot

"MRS. ALLONBY. They say, Lady Hunstanton, that when good Americans die they go to Paris. LADY HUNSTANTON. Indeed? And when bad Americans die, where do they go to? LORD ILLINGWORTH. I am not sure if Oscar Wilde would regard himself as a feminist, but his stage plays certainly provide much that would appeal to advocates of womenâ€™s rights. The inferior social position of women in the late nineteenth century, and the imbalanced moral judgements that society imposes on women are recurring themes in Wildeâ€™s plays.We might even say that the women are the stronger characters and the driving forces in all of Wildeâ€™s plays. In Lady Windermereâ€™s Fan and An Ideal Husband, the action is propelled by the female characters, and the male characters act only in reaction to the situation that has been created by the women.The men move the story along in The Importance of Being Earnest, but the women prove to be more than a match for them, and it is clear who calls the shots. Salome tells the story of a frustrated and baulked woman who finds other ways to use the power that society has denied her, rather like Hedda Tesman in Ibsenâ€™s play, Hedda Gabler.In A Woman of No Importance, the action is not led by any of the characters, but it is clear that the main moral issue presented by the play relates to the mistreatment of a woman, and that it is with her that Wildeâ€™s sympathy lies. To Lord Illingworth, Mrs Arbuthnot is a woman of no importance, a former mistress who left him when he refused to marry her so their child could be born in wedlock. It is harder to appreciate the significance of this today, and the modern reader might be irritated by Mrs Arbuthnotâ€™s constant self-abasement and brooding on her sins. However Victorian morality held that sex outside wedlock was wrong, and that the woman who did so was tainted and disgraced, unfit to form part of good society. This creates a dilemma for Mrs Arbuthnot who has concealed her past from everyone, including her son, Gerald. Now Gerald wishes to improve his social status by becoming the secretary of Lord Illingworth, unaware that the aristocrat is his father. To complicate matters Gerald is in love with an American Puritan called (what else?) Hester. Clearly Wilde has heard of The Scarlet Letter. This Puritan is untainted however, and disapproves of women who sin outside of wedlock.To stay quiet about Lord Illingworthâ€™s relation to Gerald is impossible for Mrs Arbuthnot. She cannot stand the thought of him benefitting from, and perhaps being corrupted by, his father. However to reveal the truth is to risk losing Geraldâ€™s regard for her, and to damage his prospects with Hester.A point that Wilde returns to again and again is the contrast between the position of Lord Illingworth and the lower status of Mrs Arbuthnot. He has committed the same sin as her, but he is respected in society and much sought-after, whereas for her an illegitimate child means ruin and censure. When Mrs Arbuthnot finally reveals the truth to her son, his first instinct is to try to force her to marry his father, thereby making their relationship respectable, even though she now despises Illingworth. We see again the absurdity of moral double standards that consider that a woman should choose an option that will make her unhappy simply because it is considered right by society.In the event, the play ends in a typical Wildean fudge. Hester proves to be surprisingly accommodating. Her morals shift overnight, and she helps Mrs Arbuthnot to persuade Gerald not to push marriage on his mother. By the end, the three of them find happiness together, and Mrs Arbuthnot rejects the attentions of Lord Illingworth. It seems that he has now become â€˜A man of no importanceâ€™.This turnaround to a happy ending may seem unsatisfactory, but it is in line with Wildeâ€™s other comedies. Wilde did not believe in asceticism, sacrifices and pure moral standards. He recognised that life is only supportable when people accept a grey compromise.Nonetheless Hesterâ€™s change of heart occurs a little too abruptly, and it is regrettable that nearly two acts of the play amble along without much happening, leaving only limited space for the denouement. However the main story is not one of Wildeâ€™s best, and involves too much hand-wringing and condemnation for my tastes.Wilde himself does not seem especially interested in his story, and so much of the play is a collection of witty aphorisms and bon mots uttered by characters that are only peripheral to the main story. The play contains many of Wildeâ€™s most famous sayings:â€œMen marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.â€â€œIt is perfectly monstrous the way people go about, nowadays, saying things against one behind one's back that are absolutely and entirely true.â€â€œThe Book of Life begins with a man and a woman in a garden. It ends with Revelations.â€â€œOne should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that would tell one anything.â€â€œThe English country gentleman galloping after a fox â€“ the unspeakable in full pursuit of the uneatable.â€How far one enjoys this play depends more on oneâ€™s appreciation of Wildeâ€™s witticisms than it does on following the story. I find Wildeâ€™s sayings mildly amusing, but not as wise or clever as they are often thought to be. However it is still possible to be charmed by Wildeâ€™s elegance and his consummate control of the English language.

This is a pretty entertaining play with a couple nuggets of truth well worth finding out, and it's filled with sayings that amuse but probably distract from what's at the heart of the play more than they add to it. IMO. But the play is more successful than not, especially if one is inclined to like Wilde, as I am, and would like to see it performed.But it seems like Wilde let loose with the aphorisms that look like they mean something but probably don't. I got tired of that. Lots of "women do this and men do that," including the famous bit about women becoming like their mothers being their tragedy and men not becoming like their fathers being theirs. That's the best one. Among the rest, some draw blood; others are too by-the-numbers to feel like they truly say anything. Probably got laughs, I suppose.It takes a while to figure out who the play is about and what's happening with them. The story of Mrs. Arbuthnot and her adult son, who's being offered an amazing position with Lord Illingworth, emerges from a lot of random dialogue in the first act, where a number of guests at Hunstanton Chase are talking about nothing in particular. Much of it tends toward the behavior of men and women, but all with a jaded, insincere, ironic tone. Lady Hunstanton, explaining why a particular young lady didn't receive an offer of marriage from Lord Illingworth: "But I believe he said her family was too large. Or was it her feet? I forget which." That's funny, and shows how ridiculous marriage had become among the upper classes of England, but it's also pointless conversation. Later: "Poor Lord Belton died three days [after eloping] of joy or gout. I forget which."It's all just fodder for endless, pointless conversations, where the details hardly mattered. That's a critique of the institution, but the reader also begins to feel that nothing means anything; nothing they say is worth attending to. When asked about uneducated people voting, Lord Illingworth says he thinks they are the only people who should. Then he cautions against taking sides, because that "is the beginning of sincerity, and earnestness follows shortly afterwards, and the human being becomes a bore." Later he says that he adores simple pleasures, adding "they are the last refuge of the complex." Maybe that means something. I can imagine something deep there, but I got the feeling that even Wilde was just tossing out jokes, hoping they sounded significant. The whole conversation seems to be just setups for clever bon mots that don't really mean much, and I started to wonder if anything would happen in the story.But we find out that there are secrets and connections and a history between people, and the story does get interesting. It's all about how women get squashed by society for sexual impropriety, but men never have any consequences. It's disappointing that religion and strict morality are taken for granted here, and the prevailing perspective, as a result, is that men should suffer as much as women do, not that women should not. That feels like a missed opportunity, even considering the time of publication. However, you can read the ending as supporting that notion, of treating "sinners" (if you must) charitably, with forgiveness, especially since the least judgmental person in the play is the religious American woman who is often referred to as "the Puritan," and she refuses at the end of the story to hold a woman's past against her.So maybe I should let that perspective get the final word on the topic.For too long, I thought we were supposed to see Illingworth as the lovable cad, like Rupert Everett's Lord Goring in An Ideal Husband. (I haven't read that play yet--it's just the movie for me so far.) Turns out--spoiler--Illingworth's just a cad. His wordplay is self-serving, not self-deprecating, and his apparent immorality is who he actually is. TBH, it all makes a lot more sense when you read the beginning the second time, supplied with backstories and true natures. I wonder if people went multiple times to the play back in the day...My favorite character, in the end, is the earnest and mocked young American woman. I don't know how she would have been received by Wilde's contemporaries, but she's just alright with me. Direct. Sincere. Forgiving. Good stuff.Lots of it is funny, and I like the story. Wilde can absolutely do "clever." Just a bit more heart early on and it would have really worked for me. Still, 4 stars--it comes close.

Wilde has not disappointed me once! He lives up to his hype. Is one of the most quotable plays I have ever read?? Probably! Quotations/dialogues that are 'fresh' and impactful; a welcome break from the platitudinous statements that we are bombarded with on social media these days!Lots of people have adorned their reviews with quotes and I myself noted many down. How darn right clever Wilde was!!!!His writing is playful and unpredictable. There are humorous lines but I wouldn't call this a comedy. I know many plays where comedy has been written in as specific characters or scenarios aside from the main plot and this shows variety and adeptness. All the writing Greats had this quality. Whether for shock value or not, it was thrilling to read the culturally non-formulaic/unobvious views of certain characters especially the arrogant Mrs Allonby in her after-dinner revelations to her all-female company.One such is example is when she revealed to them the following:'When Ernest and I were engaged, he swore to me positively on his knees that he had never loved any one before in the whole course of his life. Unfortunately however I made no inquiries of any kind till after I had been married four or five months. I found out then that what he had told me was perfectly true. And that sort of thing makes a man so absolutely uninteresting'Then...'I don't think the frivolity of the wife has anything to do with it. More marriages are ruined nowadays by the common sense of the husband than by anything else. How can a woman be expected to be happy with a man who insists on treating her as if she was a perfectly rational being?'And.... ' The ideal husband? There couldnt be such a thing. The institution is wrong'Published in 1894 I find it useful to put myself in the time and understand the climate - socially, politically etc to get the most out of the writing but this play is full of surprises. His characters make many insane characters of his counterparts' plays look like they were the sanest of people. And yet there is a moral plot. Even for that period, late 19th century, the ending sequence is still relevant today. A justice had been served and 'right' was done despite what the climate at that time had generally prescribed in terms of children out of wedlock etc. Wilde was well ahead of his time. Noone needs me to tell them that.Now for my favourite quotes!1. Hester: I dislike London dinner partiesMrs A: I adore them. The clever people never listen and the stupid people never talk.Hester: I think the stupid people talk a great deal.Mrs A: Ah, I never listen!2.Lord Illingworth: The soul is born old but grows young. That is the comedy of life.Mrs A: And the body is born young and grows old. That is life's tragedy.3.Lord Illingworth: Discontent is the first step in the progress of a man or a nation.4.Lord Illingworth: People nowadays are so absolutely superficial that they don't understand the philosophy of the superficial.5.Lord Illingworth: All thought is immoral. Its very essence is destruction. If you think of anything, you kill it. Nothing survives being thought of.

Oscar Wild's writing is pure wit and intelligence. He makes you laugh, he makes you think. He was a man so aware of how ludicrous upper-class society was and his mockery of its people is clear in his every satirical work. He isn't afraid to point out how superficial and idiotic the women are and has no qualms pointing out how arrogant and egotistical the men are.He has a very clever way of exposing high society life as being little more than low society in fancier clothes and big draughty halls.A Woman of No Importance isn't as light and comical as, say, The Importance of Being Ernest, though it has its moments, instead, it presents a harsher aspect of society, exhibiting how unjustly women were treated. If a man did wrong is was accepted simply as the usual and even fanciful behaviour of a man; a sort of 'boys will be boys' understanding. But if a woman does wrong she is condemned, disgraced and cast of from society life, forcing her to either accept her dishonourable fate or live a lie. This play highlights perfectly the condemnation of woman against woman, more so even than men. I almost got the sense that a man wouldn't particularly care about a woman's past or her lost virtues, but it is the women who are quick to judge whilst being uninformed on the matter altogether.I was very pleased with Mrs Arbuthnot's decision at the end regarding Lord Illingworth. After what he did and how callous he was with her feelings, he didn't deserve a moment of her time. It was great to see a woman from a play of Victorian times stand up for herself and tell the obnoxious man where to stick it. I was a little worried the play would end in romance (undeserved on Illingworth's part) but thankfully Wilde didn't write Mrs Arbuthnot as an insipid female ready to throw herself into the arms of a former lover, ignoring his past misdemeanours. A very satisfying ending indeed.The tension and drama in this play were delicious and the writing, of course, was masterful. I don't expect anything less from Wilde. I could see the comedic moments on a stage with Lady Caroline passing from room to room always looking for Sir John, and I imagine it would be very funny.I'd really like to see this performed live sometime as the wit of Oscar Wilde is truly something that needs to be experienced firsthand. The standout quotes to me were,"When a man is old enough to do wrong he should be old enough to do right also.""Duty is what one expects from others, it is not what one does oneself.""The only difference between the saint and the sinner is that every saint has a past and every sinner has a future."

I LOVED IT. I feel very touched by it, especially the ending. I started reading it because sometimes I just find myself wanting to read about a bunch of familiar characters speaking Oscar Wilde, but I did not expect for him to outdo himself like this. I loved the feminism and the gentle love in it. He really has so many Opinions about shame and double standards which are so lovely to read, and just wants love and good things for everybody who's decent (and his and society's views of decency are very, very different). He was such a sweet, dear moralist at heart and wasn't even bothering to disguise that with too many aphorisms here. I think I've found my favourite Oscar Wilde play.HESTER. If a man and woman have sinned, let them both go forth into the desert to love or loathe each other there. Let them both be branded. Set a mark, if you wish, on each, but donâ€™t punish the one and let the other go free. Donâ€™t have one law for men and another for women. MRS. ARBUTHNOT. Only love can keep any one alive. HESTER. You cannot love me at all, unless you love her also. You cannot honour me, unless sheâ€™s holier to you. In her all womanhood is martyred. Not she alone, but all of us are stricken in her house.MRS. ARBUTHNOT. [To Hester.] But has he found indeed another love?HESTER. You know I have loved him always.MRS. ARBUTHNOT. But we are very poor.HESTER. Who, being loved, is poor? Oh, no one. I hate my riches. They are a burden. Let him share it with me.MRS. ARBUTHNOT. But we are disgraced. We rank among the outcasts. Gerald is nameless. The sins of the parents should be visited on the children. It is Godâ€™s law.HESTER. I was wrong. Godâ€™s law is only Love.

Happened in a series of events over a short period from a house party of high-class society in the Victorian era, lashings of audacious absurdity, and gender manipulations from social satires that a modern personâ€™s sanity will be tested if be read in todayâ€™s era.A start from the eliteâ€™s mockery of middle-class society to emphasize the gloriousness of the superiority of the upper class, slowly unraveling in each page the reeking smell of their hidden vices and mischief, making a point of how women should only be â€œplaythingâ€ and doesnâ€™t deserve an intellect that can debate a man, and ending all these series of events in a short period by giving justice to an exposed concealed secret for twenty years which turns out that this particular man named Lord Illingworth who has always something big to say ended up in being a man of no importance to the thing that is most precious to him other than his wealth and title, his son.An abundance of impactful and debatable lines was overflowing in this book and I want to share with you some of the most compelling lines that I have read.ğŸŒ· â€œLife, Lady Stutfield, is simply a mauvais quart dâ€™heure made up of exquisite moments.â€ğŸŒ· â€œPeople now-a-days are so absolutely superficial that they donâ€™t understand the philosophy of the superficial.â€ğŸŒ· â€œThe secret of life is never to have an emotion that is unbecoming.â€ğŸŒ· â€œbut position and money are not everything, are they?â€ â€œThey are nothing; they bring misery.â€ğŸŒ· â€œHearts live by becoming wounded. Pleasure may turn a heart to stone, riches may make it callous, but sorrowâ€”oh, sorrow can not break it.â€

This play is somewhat more moralizing and biting that some of Wilde's works, in my opinion as is deals ably with the conventions and social mores of the time and their inherent hypocrisies. Of course, this is true of all his work but seems particularly the case here. That is not to say that the famous and wonderful whimsy and witty wordplays are not to the fore as well as they certainly are. However in "The Importance of being Earnest" the rogues in the play are likeable and their witticisms therefore seem more congruous than they do here, in the mouth of Lord Illingworth. This character is shameless and, although funny as most of Wilde's characters are, has few redeeming features and leaves at the curtain basically the same nasty character. This is actually refreshing as there is no happy ending here, but again, the whole seems a little discordant. That may be the point and one that I have missed. I love the writings of Oscar Wilde. The more one reads him the more one finds some of his witticisms to be written long similar lines, but they are laugh out loud funny and to quote the extremely pithy Monty Python sketch makes one think: "I wish I had said that". When you overlay this on top of his social satire and commentary, you have a genius indeed. I know he is widely admired but probably never enough in his later life. This is perhaps not a masterpiece but is a great play - reading it makes me desirous of a trip to see this performed live again where it, of course, really comes to life.

Gerald is a young man who secures an appointment as secretary to the rich and flirtatious ambassador, Lord Illingworth. His mother objects to the moral character of his new employer, but can give no concrete reason without revealing her dark past. Gerald is determined to accept the post, because he is in love with a young American lady and needs the money to get married. Throughout the play, various rich and titled characters gossip about London high society, and flirt with each other, and say a lot of shameless nonsense.One of the main reasons why I love Oscar Wilde's hilarious plays is the silly dialogue. The characters say such idiotic things, and it always makes me laugh. Almost the entire first act is fluff and character introductions, but it is such entertaining fluff that I didn't mind. Of course, the social commentary is an undercurrent that lies under every scene, exposing the rich elite as vapid, immoral, and selfish.I really enjoyed the plot in this one, and the conflict that Gerald and his mother experience keeps the story moving forward. The last act gets more serious, and the drama is quite passionate.I was intrigued by the main characters, and appreciated the gradual unveiling of their personalities. I was imagining their dialogue in my head as I read it, wondering how they would say the lines, and what their expression and body language would be. They are extremely vivid and lively even on paper!

What an extraordinary book!This is my first time reading a play, it was hard for me to get into this kind of writing but Oscar made it surely amazing.His spectacular writing and the work behind of it, that after you finish reading you get that feeling of â€œoh what a good bookâ€.In the story we get to see point of views of men and women at the Victorian age and a lot of prejudice and way of thinking back then on women and man and their meaning in life.About modernism, sexism, feminism, thoughts, and more.You get to learn a lot about these kind of things and how thinking has changed throughout the years.The book is told from both of the gendersâ€™ perspectives, about a womanâ€™s life being ruined over a man who promised to marry her but never did and left her with a child. How people seem to get the idea that a fault of that kind is a womanâ€™s fault and a punishment should be given always to the woman.But the woman although seemed in their society back then as a woman of no importance, gathering all her pain in life and refusing to marry the man who ruined her life once he asks for his advantage, out of his selfishness for wanting his child to be his. The woman is shown as a brave, caring, intelligent, independent mother, woman and simply as a person, she stands out from the rest and the thinking style back then. It is the last sentence â€œa man of no importanceâ€ who truly get you to realise how sophisticated is Wilde.

"Ah! The world was made for men and not for women.Oh, don't say that, Lady Stutfield. We have a much better time than they have. There are far more things forbiden." "Curious thing, plain women are always jealous of their husbands, beautiful women never are!""London dinner-parties.I adore them. The clever people never listen, and the stupid people never talk.I think the stupid people talk a great deal.Ah, I never listen!" "The soul is born old but grows young. That is the comedy of life.And the body is born young and grows old that is life's tragedy.""Men always want to be a women's first love. That is their clumsy vanity. We women have a more subtle instinct about things. What we like is to be a man's last romance.""Don't have one law for men and another for women. You are injust to women in England. And till you count what is a shame in a woman to be an infamy in a man, you will always be injust.""All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy.No man does. That is his.""And the ending is the ordinary ending. The woman suffers. The man goes free.""Women are hard on each other."Always a pleasure to read Oscar Wilde. Shameful the way he was treated in his own country. Other times, hypocritical conduct and morals. Unfortunately this is still valid today.

I bought a collection of Wilde's plays after enjoying "The Importance of Being Earnest" so much. Since then, I have read some of his more prominent works, and he has never failed to make me chuckle and haw at random moments in reading.So imagine my surprise at tearing up at the end of this one. Where others of his plays end as light and fluffy as they began, with simple and positive messages such as forgiveness or enjoying life on a shallower scale, this story felt very emotional in contrast. The monologues on dealing with shame make me wonder if they came from Wilde's own heart, and don't fall far from the exact same issues we deal with today. I don't know much about Wilde's personal story besides his jail time for homosexuality, but I do wonder if the burden of living with his societal and religious shame came through in this play. Additionally, the optimistic, idealistic, and often misguided American character serves as hope here. She offers the chance at freedom, of change, of possibility, in comparison to the stagnant structures of English society. I really enjoyed this. My only dislikes, such as not knowing the characters for 3/4 of the play, are probably due to the injustice of reading and not watching it, which I hope to do anyway sometime this week.I'll make sure to bring tissues with me~

"the world is made for men, not for womenâ€.Not as funny as his other plays, and not as well written, with more than a touch of the sentimental; still I don't mind that too much, nor do I mind the slow first act which just lingers on a bit too long, because it does something none of Wilde's other plays do: it shows the darker side of the whole dandy lifestyle. Wilde's dandy's can easily utter things like: â€œTo win back my youth, there is nothing I wouldn't do - except take exercise, get up early, or be a useful member of the community.â€or:â€œMy dear young lady, there was a great deal of truth; I dare say, in what you said, and you looked very pretty while you said it, which is much more important.â€ Without any consequences whatsoever. But in this play, there are consequences, and the burdens fall plainly on the women, who have to suffer when the men go of scot-free. It is a quite feminist, harsh satire of Victorian England. It pierces all the ingenuity, dishonesty and casual, albeit funny, sexism, and even if it does so with more than a touch of the dramatic and old-fashioned, it is still quite refreshing to hear a 19th century character tell a high and mighty lord that she does not find his marriage proposal as generous as he thinks it is, but would rather say alone.

Oscar Wilde is one of my favorites of all time . His points of view and quotes are unmatched and equipped with a terrible moral that is timeless and refreshing . A Woman of No Importance does much to really put Wildeâ€™s points of view in sheer brilliance. It reads like his essays but with a satirical edge and tough criticism of the 19th century. I particularly loved the fluidity of the play and the uncomplicated settings . The character portraits were economical and the dramatis was fairly easy to follow . Lord Illingworth will give you a think and Lady Caroline a hearty laugh whilst Hester Worster serves as the reflection to societyâ€™s ills . Probably one of his best plays and a very worthy read. There are so many ways to view this play . It can be a feminist, critical , social commentary on class etc . I canâ€™t to re read it and visit it with new lenses.Favorite quotes : â€œMen always want to be a woman's first love. That is their clumsy vanity. We women have a more subtle instinct about things. What we like is to be a man's last romance.â€ This gave me Persuasion vibes . â€œThe only difference between the saint and the sinner is that every saint has a past, and every sinner has a futureâ€

Wow. This play packs an emotional punch. While the plot does not really pick up until near the end of the second act (although if you enjoy Wildeâ€™s witticism and social commentary like I do, youâ€™ll still thoroughly enjoy the first act), once it starts, it is phenomenal. Wildeâ€™s criticism of societyâ€™s double standard for men and women, especially in regards to extramarital sex (although he manages to touch on a wide variety of topics dealing with women during this time period), is absolutely amazing. I especially enjoyed Act 4. The motherâ€™s character is just so raw and tormented, itâ€™s impossible not to ache for her (I thought her story was very similar to Fantineâ€™s from Les Miserables, both in plot and emotional impact). And Lord Illingworth is so horribly despicableâ€”very similar to Lord Henry from The Picture of Dorian Grayâ€”I hated him completely. I definitely enjoyed this play as much as The Importance of Being Earnest. While it had none of that playâ€™s side-splitting hilarity, it was much more impactful. Whether or not youâ€™re a Wilde fan, I would definitely recommend this play. (Side note: Many of the themes reminded me of Henrik Ibsenâ€™s â€œA Dollâ€™s House.â€ They share many similarities in how they address the topic of unfair treatment towards women.)

Wilde's witticisms and constant satirical dialogue was the most enjoyable part of the book, (as well as the ending of course!). I wished that Hester was a more nuanced and complex character as she had such strong opinions and was quite confident yet in the book she was kind of written off as a bit of a damsel in distress. I guess that might be because of the time this play was made, and my much more modern views on politics and gender. She is the reason for the good ending though and she was a good character, overall. I found myself hating almost every other character due to their absurd outlooks on life and society but I guess that comes down to Wilde's ability to write realistic and silly characters really well. In my opinion, I found the main and most important characters (Hestor, Mrs. Arbuthnot, Gerald, Mr. Illingworth... especially Illingworth) to be kind of pathetic in parts. This took away a bit of likeability from Hestor, Mrs. Arbuthnot and Gerald but not too much so that I disliked them.Some of the dialogue is long-winded and sometimes the plot frustrates me but was a pretty good read in the end."Hallo, mother, whose glove is this? You have had a visitor, who was it?""Oh! no one. No one in particular. A man of no importance".

The title "A Man of No Importance" would capture the essence of this story, as it is said by Mrs Arbuthnot in the end. I couldn't agree more.It is always wonderful to read Oscar Wilde's works, stands true to the thoughts and conversation we have in this century. I guess nothing really changed.The pep talk from Lord Illingworth to Gerald draws parallel to the chat between Henry Wotton and Dorian Gray. I found their conversations quite similar when they talked of youth in particular. The other characters found Lord Illingworth to be of an immoral nature, he knew how to talk, influence people and he said that a man who can rule over London's dinner table can rule the word. The same can be described about Lord Henry Wotton.The one character that amused me so much, was the wife of Dr. Daubeny. She was not physically present, but is a topic of conversation between the Doctor and Mrs Hunstanton. The excuses he gives of his wife's ill health, which leaves her incapable of attending social gatherings makes me suspicious. She could be someone who doesn't prefer crowd, or despises Mrs Hunstanton in particular. We will never know.

Just brilliant. I love Wilde's description of men and women and their relationships. He gets it spot on every time. I would go on but fear I may get emotional.One should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that would tell one anything.Men always want to be a woman's first love. That is their clumsy vanity. We women have a more subtle instinct about things. What we want is to be a man's last romance.He should never run down other pretty women. That would show he has no taste, or make one suspect that he has too much.Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.When good Americans die they go to Paris....And when bad Americans die, ...they go to America.We have the largest country in the world, Lady Caroline. They used to tell us at school that some of our states are as big as France and England put together.Ah! you must find it very draughty, I should fancy.What do you think she'd do if I kissed her?Either marry you, or strike you across the face with her glove. What would you do if she struck you across the face with her glove?Fall in love with her, probably.

This is very witty, and as with the other plays I've read by Wilde, I recognise a number of lines. He's certainly a very quotable writer! I can't help but think that more attention has been given to the prose than to the story, however - and it does seem a bit lumpen, that story. Perhaps it's because the romance in it is only a secondary thing, between two secondary characters? For the most part it's a straight drama that centres on the confrontation of Lord Illingham with the woman who, twenty years ago, he'd seduced and abandoned. Much of the play is concerned with the differing standards that men and women are held to under such circumstances: she is ruined, while he is allowed back into decent society, even if he is the more at fault. I'm completely with Wilde on this, and I suspect with a very good actress Mrs. Arbuthnot would be enormously affecting - she's affecting even when only reading the play - but I read Lady Windermere's Fan a couple of days ago, also by Wilde, and when it comes to portraits of so-called fallen women, Mrs. Erlynne leaves Mrs. Arbuthnot for dead.

The character dynamics, relationships and interactions were executed perfectly and I loved the subliminal girl-power messaging as it's so ahead of its time.
